So I think those are all important, exciting use cases to think about.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Well I want to ask a more near-term question, near and dear to my heart — kind of about media and publishing, but also search on the web. Today, lots of digital publishers rely on the traffic they get from Google. They get ad impressions. That pays their bills.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">When Bard is at its best, it answers my questions without me having to visit another website. I know you’re cognizant of this. But man, if Bard gets as good as you want it to be, how does the web survive?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichai</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I think through our work across, I think we’ll be committed to getting it right with the publisher ecosystem. In search today, while these things are contentious, in search, we take pride, it’s one of the largest sources of traffic. If I look at it year-on-year, the traffic we send outside has only grown. That’s what we’ve accomplished as a company.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">Part of the reason we are also being careful with things like Bard, amongst many reasons, we do want to engage with the publisher ecosystem, not presume how things should be done. And so you will see us thoughtfully evolve there as well.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, I mean, I know we can’t really predict what the final form of all of this stuff will be, but I have to believe that, I don’t know, in five years, what used to be the Google Search Bar is just essentially a command line that I can write in to get anything I want — whether I want to change something on my phone, write myself a little app, access the subtotal of human knowledge, have it draft my emails. Does that feel like a potential final destination to you, or do I have it all wrong?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichai</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, I mean, there’s a part which is consistent with our mission to do that. But I think I want to be careful where Google has always been about helping you the way that makes sense to you. We have never thought of ourselves as the be-all and end-all of how we want people to interact.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So while I think the possibility space is large, for me, it’s important to do it in a way in which users use a lot of things, and we want to help them do things in a way that makes sense to them. But I don’t want to get it — so that’s the way I think about it, at least in my head.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Sundar, thank you for joining us.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Thank you, Sundar.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Thanks, Kevin, Casey. Thank you for that enlightening and enriching road trip, and also for allowing us to stop at In and Out for lunch on the way back.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, it turns out if you order your fries well done, which is not on the menu, they arrive much crispier and more delicious.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, that’s a pro tip for you.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, that wasn’t my only takeaway from today, Kevin.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, what’d you think?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, you know, a lot of times when companies tell us about the new technologies they’re introducing, they do so in a really grandiose way. And I was struck today by the humility that Sundar uses when he talks about where the company is now. He is not here to tell you that Bard is the best language model out there. He said that, in fact, it is quite limited.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, he said — he compared it to a souped-up Civic.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">[LAUGHS]: Yeah, which I wasn’t expecting. And man, I’m really curious to see if Bard feels any different in a few days.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, and I really was struck by what he called “whiplash,” where he’s got people telling him, you know, you’ve got to move faster, and compete with GPT, and release everything you’ve got — and then, also, this very real sense of like, didn’t we get in trouble for doing this the last time with, you know, all the products that we released in the last decade? Shouldn’t we be slow and deliberate? So I would want to switch jobs with them.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">It sounds very hard.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Also, I thought we would mostly be solving mysteries this week, but I feel like we are leaving with one, which is, who did order the Code Red at that company?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, if you ordered the Code Red at Google, please write to us at hardfork@nytimes.com.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">We would love to hear from you.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Also, before we go this week, a special thanks to the listener who wrote in to tell us that Spotify has a feature that allows you to exclude certain playlists, like my Sleep playlist, from your taste profile, which informs your recommendations and possibly what the AI DJ tells you to listen to.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, I did that this week. class="css-1nng8z9">transcript</p><h2 class="css-9wqu2x">Google C.E.O. Sundar Pichai on Bard, A.I. ‘Whiplash’ and Competing With ChatGPT</h2><h4 class="css-qsd3hm">“Am I concerned? Yes. Am I optimistic and excited about all the potential of this technology? Incredibly.”</h4><time dateTime="2023-03-31T09:00:12.000Z" class="css-1e6es05">Friday, March 31st, 2023</time></div><dl class="css-p98d0w"><dt class="css-xx7kwh"></dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">This transcript was created using speech recognition software. While it has been reviewed by human transcribers, it may contain errors. Please review the episode audio before quoting from this transcript and email transcripts@nytimes.com with any questions.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">So as of last week, Bard, Google’s effort at building consumer-grade AI, is out in the world. And I think it’s fair to say the early reviews were not amazing. And I sort of imagined that we would discuss that at a really high level this week. But then last week, I got a phone call.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">And someone I know at Google said, would you maybe want to talk this week to Sundar Pichai? And I said yes.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">That didn’t take you a lot of deliberation on that one.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">[MUSIC PLAYING]</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">I’m Kevin Roose. I’m a tech columnist at “The New York Times.”</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I’m Casey Newton from “Platformer.”</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">And you’re listening to “Hard Fork.” This week, we hit the road and take a trip to the Googleplex to talk to Google’s CEO, Sundar Pichai.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">[MUSIC PLAYING]</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So last week, we talked about Google’s new chat bot called Bard, which is supposed to be their answer to ChatGPT and some of these other generative AI chat bots. And I think it’s safe to say that the reaction among the public to Bard so far has been pretty lukewarm. My Twitter timeline is not full of screenshots of Bard conversations like it was of ChatGPT conversations late last year when that came out. It doesn’t seem to have landed with nearly as big a splash.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">It was a little muted. You know, I think by this point, a lot of people have tried chat bots. And they feel like ChatGPT in particular gives really good results. And I think when people put these things through their paces, a lot of people felt like, I’m not sure if Bard is as good.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. And that kind of fits with this narrative that has been developing in the AI community over the past year or two, which is that Google is somehow behind in this race for generative AI. They’ve been working on this stuff for a long time. Google certainly had a dominant position in AI research for many years. They came out with this thing, the Transformer, that revolutionized the field of AI and created the foundations for ChatGPT and all these other programs.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">But then the perception, at least, is that they kind of fell behind. A lot of their researchers left and did their own startups or went to competitors. They didn’t really turn their research into products at a pace that people could actually use and appreciate. And they got sort of hamstrung by a lot of — to hear people inside Google tell it — big company politics and bureaucracy. And I think it’s safe to say that they got sort of upstaged by OpenAI.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">With the release of ChatGPT last year, it seemed to catch Google off guard. And so in December, just a month after ChatGPT came out, my colleagues at “The New York Times” reported that Google’s management had declared a code red.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah. And look, if you’re a business and you’re developing a lot of amazing technology, and no one else out there has released similar technology, that gives you a good reason to stay quiet and to not release it, right? We know that there are real safety concerns. There’s responsibility issues, ethics issues, regulatory issues.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">Google actually did have a lot of good reasons to kind of sit on its hands. But then OpenAI forced its hand, and in a way that makes me wish I had used hands in a different way in the previous sentence because now I’ve just said hands too many times. Anyways, I love how dramatic a code red sounds. Makes you think like, what, are employees chained to their desks 24/7?</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">My understanding is that what it meant for a lot of people there was all of a sudden, the goals that you had to get your next promotion, get your bonus, they were tied to whether you hit some goal related to AI. And the question is, is that going to get them where they want to go, or is it going to be a moment where they act a little panicked and they make a lot of mistakes?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah. And I think that Sundar Pichai is in a really fascinating and tough position here as the CEO of Google. And I think it’s fair to say that they are more threatened than they have been in a very long time.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">That’s right. And Google has been a relatively conflict-averse company for the past half decade-plus. They don’t like picking fights. If they can just keep their heads down, quietly do their work, and print money with a monopolistic search advertising business, they’re happy to do it.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Totally. And they also have this other problem, which is kind of a classic problem in business, which is the innovator’s dilemma problem. This is a term that was coined by Clayton Christensen a long time ago. It’s used to talk about the dynamics between new startups that enter a market and the incumbents in that market.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">And basically, Google is in the position of an incumbent. It has this huge, profitable search business that it doesn’t want to sort of diminish or leave behind in any way. At the same time, it’s got OpenAI and now Microsoft, which is partnering with OpenAI, who are potentially eating into their search business using these generative AI tools. And so they have to somehow figure out, how do we capitalize on generative AI without destroying our own search business?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Sometimes as a business journalist, you look at a situation, and you say, well, I know exactly what I would do there. But when you present me with the problem that Google has right now, which is, how do you introduce generative AI and not blow up our whole search advertising business, that seems like a very tricky problem to me.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">But I am not as certain as you are that there is a real existential risk here, although there might be. I do think that there is a real generational opportunity, though — that if they figure this out, there is a chance that they become an even more enormous company than they are today. Google plays a huge role in my life. That’s where my email is. That’s how I get around town. It’s how I waste hours of my life on YouTube.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">And when they introduce these generative tools across their entire suite of products in ways that we haven’t even imagined yet, there’s going to be enormous opportunity for them both financially, but also to kind of set the pace again. And so I think one of the big questions heading into this interview is, is Google truly slow because of the nature of huge companies being unable to be nimble, or have they truly been trying to be safer and more responsible from some of their peers at a time when a lot of really smart people are starting to ring alarm bells and saying, this stuff is moving awfully fast, and we’re not sure that you’ve done all the safety work that you need to?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. Was your homework late because you were taking extra time to make sure it was good, or did you just decide to go to the club and not do your homework? That’s a horrible analogy.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, I decided to go to the club.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So we have a lot of questions. And I talked with Google last week. They said that Sundar would sit down with us and talk about these questions and more. So you and I are going to take a road trip to ask the man himself.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">We are. Are you driving?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">You’re driving, I’m hoping.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I’m driving.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Are you driving?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, I’ll pick you up.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Oh, that’s fantastic.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I’ve got to clean my car.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah. I’ll send you the link on Google Maps.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">[MUSIC PLAYING]</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichai</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Either way, that’s my water or someone else’s water. Oh, there’s my water. Thank you.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">All right. Sundar Pichai, welcome to “Hard Fork.”</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichai</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Great to be here. So for example, I would make sure we get privacy regulation right. So because if we have a foundational approach to privacy, that should apply to a technologies, too.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichai</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I think there are many areas people underestimate where there are strong regulations already in place. Like, health care is a very regulated industry, right? And so when AI is going to come in, it has to conform with all regulations.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So you also want to build on existing regulation where you can. I think that would allow innovation to proceed as well. Once you start getting into specifics like that, I think what I would be worried about is, this is such fast-evolving technology. Being very opinionated early on, I think, is difficult.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">But I think notions of transparency, where people are aware of what other people are doing, has some element of reasonableness to it, how easy it is to do at a global scale, I think those are hard. The thing that gives me hope is I’ve never seen a technology in its earliest days with as much concern as AI.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">And just one more thing on this letter calling for this six-month pause. Are you willing to entertain that idea? I know you haven’t committed to it, but is that something you think Google would do?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">So I think in the actual specifics of it, it’s not fully clear to me. How would you do something like that, right, today?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, you could send an email to your engineers and say, OK, we’re going to take a six-month break.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">No, no, no, but How would you do — but if others aren’t doing that. So what does that mean? I’m talking about the how would you effectively —</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s sort of a collective action problem.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">To me at least there is no way to do this effectively without getting governments involved.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">So I think there’s a lot more thought that needs to go into it. I think the people behind it intended it, probably, as a conversation starter. And so I think the spirit of it is, I think, good, but I think we need to take our time thinking through these things.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah. There’s sort of two categories of AI risk that people are worried about. There’s sort of the short-term worries — the chat bots that get things wrong, or maybe they’re biased or they’re giving people bad answers. Then, there’s the kind of long-term or longer-term worries about, frankly, AI destroying human civilization.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, has talked about the possibility of AGI, this artificial general intelligence that could become super human and effect dramatic and bad change in the world. Do you believe that we’re headed toward AGI? And, do you want to build that?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">It is so clear to me that these systems are going to be very, very capable. And so it almost doesn’t matter whether you’ve reached AGI or not. You’re going to have systems which are capable of delivering benefits at a scale we have never seen before and potentially causing real harm.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So can we have an AI system which can cost disinformation at scale? Yes. Is it AGI? It really doesn’t matter. Why do we need to worry about AI safety? Because you have to anticipate this and evolve to meet that moment. And so today, we do a lot of things with AI people have taken it for granted.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Right? Think about how big a moment Deep Blue was, or when we did AlphaGo. But you can’t take it all for granted. And so I think this will play out differently than thinking through a moment like AGI.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Right, there is that thing where people just refer to anything you can’t do yet as something AI will handle in the future. I remember the first time I searched Google Photos for dogs, and it just showed me all the dogs on my Camera Roll. I mean, that is AI, at least by some definitions. But I think you’re right — people do take it for granted.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">And I remember when we launched Photos, we had to explain at Google IO what neural networks were, what deep learning was, and we’re trying to explain that this is different technology. This is — yeah, it’s interesting.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, so if you had to give a question on the AGI or the more long-term concerns, what would you say is the chance that a more advanced AI could lead to the destruction of humanity?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">There is a spectrum of possibilities. And what you’re saying is in one of that possibility ranges, right? And so if you look at even the current debate about where AI is today or where LLMs are, you see people who are strongly opinionated on either side.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">There are a set of who believe these LLMs, they’re just not that powerful. They are statistical models which are —</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">They’re just fancy autocomplete.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yes, that’s one way of putting it, right. And there are people who are looking at this and saying, these are really powerful technologies. You can see emergent capabilities — and so on.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">We could hit a wall two iterations down. I don’t think so, but that’s a possibility. They could really progress in a two-year time frame. And so we have to really make sure we are vigilant and working with it.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">One of the things that gives me hope about AI, like climate change, is it affects everyone. And so these are both issues that have similar characteristics in the sense that you can’t unilaterally get safety in AI. By definition, it affects everyone. So that tells me the collective will come over time to tackle all of this responsibly.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So I’m optimistic about it because I think people will care and people will respond. But the right way to do that is by being concerned about it. So I would never — at least for me, I would never dismiss any of the concerns, and I’m glad people are taking it seriously. We will.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, it just strikes me that you are in such a tricky position because you have this one group of people that’s saying, like, move faster. Release the stuff faster. Go compete with all these other people. You built all this technology. Don’t let that lead go to waste.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">And then you have other people saying what Kevin just said, which is like there’s a non-zero risk that this stuff does something really, really bad. What is that like for you, waking up every day and just having both of those things in your ear?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">There is a sense of some whiplash, ? Right it’s like asking, hey, why aren’t you moving fast and breaking things again?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Which, for all of us, over the past few years. I think we realize we are going to be bold and responsible. We are working with urgency. We are excited at this moment. There’s so much we can do. So you will see us be bold and ship things, but we are going to be very responsible in how we do it.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So there will be times when we will hold back things. I think what we are doing in Bard, for us, is an example of it. We haven’t hooked up Bard to our most capable models yet, and we plan to do it deliberately. And so through this moment, I think we are going to stay balanced, but we are going to innovate. And there is a genuine excitement at this moment, so we’ll do that.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I hear you saying that what gives you hope for the future when it comes to AI is that other people are concerned about it — that they’re looking at the risks and the challenges. So on one hand, you’re saying that people should be concerned about AI. On the other hand, you’re saying the fact that they are concerned about AI makes you less concerned. So which is —</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Sorry, I’m saying the fact that the way you get things wrong is by not worrying about it. So if you don’t worry about something, you’re just going to completely get surprised. So to me, it gives me hope that there is a lot of people — important people — who are very concerned, and rightfully so.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">Am I concerned? Yes. Am I optimistic and excited about all the potential of this technology? Incredibly. I mean, we’ve been working on this for a long time. But I think the fact that so many people are concerned gives me hope that we will rise over time and tackle what we need to do.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">So we should continue to write columns where we’re very nervous about where all this is going?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">As well as columnns where you’re excited about the possible benefits of all of this.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, I hear you on the whiplash. I feel whiplash every day just reading the news about AI. I can only imagine what you’re feeling.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I do too.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Another question that people have about AI in the sort of medium and long term is about its effects on jobs. And there have been all these predictions about LLMs and what kinds of work they could replace or will replace. I actually — I got a text from a software engineer a friend of mine the other day who was asking me if he should go into construction or welding because all of the software jobs are going to be taken by these large language models.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">And he was sort of joking, but sort of not. You have a lot of software engineers here at Google that work for you. How should they feel about that question?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">With any technology, you have adaptation. I think this one, there’ll be a lot of societal adaptation. And as part of that, we all may need to course-correct in certain areas.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">To your specific question, I think for software engineers, there are two things that will also be true. One is some of the grunt work you’re doing as part of programming is going to get better. So maybe it’ll be more fun to program over time — no different from the Google Docs make it easier to write. And so if you’re a programmer, over time, having this collaborative IDs with the assistance built in, I think, is going to make it easier.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">The other thing that excites me is programming is going to become more accessible to more people. And so it’s such an important role in the world. You’re creating things. And today, the bar is very high.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So we are going to evolve to a more natural language way of programming over time. So to me, that means things no different from to do a podcast — to do something like this 40 years ago, just imagine what access you would need to have to be able to do an interview like this.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">We need a radio tower — [LAUGHS]</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">[LAUGHS]:</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">But you know, but we will think, this has enabled more people.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I think the same thing will be true for software engineering as well. So I think those are all important, exciting use cases to think about.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Well I want to ask a more near-term question, near and dear to my heart — kind of about media and publishing, but also search on the web. Today, lots of digital publishers rely on the traffic they get from Google. They get ad impressions. That pays their bills.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">When Bard is at its best, it answers my questions without me having to visit another website. I know you’re cognizant of this. But man, if Bard gets as good as you want it to be, how does the web survive?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichai</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">I think through our work across, I think we’ll be committed to getting it right with the publisher ecosystem. In search today, while these things are contentious, in search, we take pride, it’s one of the largest sources of traffic. If I look at it year-on-year, the traffic we send outside has only grown. That’s what we’ve accomplished as a company.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">Part of the reason we are also being careful with things like Bard, amongst many reasons, we do want to engage with the publisher ecosystem, not presume how things should be done. And so you will see us thoughtfully evolve there as well.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, I mean, I know we can’t really predict what the final form of all of this stuff will be, but I have to believe that, I don’t know, in five years, what used to be the Google Search Bar is just essentially a command line that I can write in to get anything I want — whether I want to change something on my phone, write myself a little app, access the subtotal of human knowledge, have it draft my emails. Does that feel like a potential final destination to you, or do I have it all wrong?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichai</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, I mean, there’s a part which is consistent with our mission to do that. But I think I want to be careful where Google has always been about helping you the way that makes sense to you. We have never thought of ourselves as the be-all and end-all of how we want people to interact.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">So while I think the possibility space is large, for me, it’s important to do it in a way in which users use a lot of things, and we want to help them do things in a way that makes sense to them. And out of that North Star is whatever the answer it leads us to. But I don’t want to get it — so that’s the way I think about it, at least in my head.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Sundar, thank you for joining us.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Thank you, Sundar.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">sundar pichal</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Thanks, Kevin, Casey. Pleasure, yeah.</p><p class="css-8hvvyd">[FUNKY MUSIC PLAYING]</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Casey, we are back from the Googleplex. I really enjoyed our little field trip today. Thank you for that enlightening and enriching road trip, and also for allowing us to stop at In and Out for lunch on the way back.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, it turns out if you order your fries well done, which is not on the menu, they arrive much crispier and more delicious.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, that’s a pro tip for you.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, that wasn’t my only takeaway from today, Kevin.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, what’d you think?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, you know, a lot of times when companies tell us about the new technologies they’re introducing, they do so in a really grandiose way. And I was struck today by the humility that Sundar uses when he talks about where the company is now. He is not here to tell you that Bard is the best language model out there. He said that, in fact, it is quite limited.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, he said — he compared it to a souped-up Civic.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">[LAUGHS]: Yeah, which I wasn’t expecting. But he broke a little news with us. He told us that Bard is going to be upgraded. And man, I’m really curious to see if Bard feels any different in a few days.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, and I really was struck by what he called “whiplash,” where he’s got people telling him, you know, you’ve got to move faster, and compete with GPT, and release everything you’ve got — and then, also, this very real sense of like, didn’t we get in trouble for doing this the last time with, you know, all the products that we released in the last decade? Shouldn’t we be slow and deliberate? So I would want to switch jobs with them.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">It sounds very hard.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Also, I thought we would mostly be solving mysteries this week, but I feel like we are leaving with one, which is, who did order the Code Red at that company?</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, if you ordered the Code Red at Google, please write to us at hardfork@nytimes.com.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">We would love to hear from you.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Also, before we go this week, a special thanks to the listener who wrote in to tell us that Spotify has a feature that allows you to exclude certain playlists, like my Sleep playlist, from your taste profile, which informs your recommendations and possibly what the AI DJ tells you to listen to.</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">casey newton</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah, I did that this week. So chill tracks will no longer be showing up in my Discover Weekly. That was a genius suggestion. Thank you to that listener — and to all of our listeners. [RHYTHMIC MUSIC]</p></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">kevin roose</dt><dd class="css-4gvq6l"><p class="css-8hvvyd">“Hard Fork” is produced by Davis Land and Rachel Cohn. We’re edited by Jen Poyant. While it has been reviewed by human transcribers, it may contain errors. Please review the episode audio before quoting from this transcript and email transcripts@nytimes.com with any questions. So as of last week, Bard, Google's effort at building consumer-grade AI, is out in the world. And I think it's fair to say the early reviews were not amazing. And I sort of imagined that we would discuss that at a really high level this week. But then last week, I got a phone call. And someone I know at Google said, would you maybe want to talk this week to Sundar Pichai? And I said yes. That didn't take you a lot of deliberation on that one. [MUSIC PLAYING] I'm Kevin Roose. I'm a tech columnist at \"The New York Times.\" I'm Casey Newton from \"Platformer.\" And you're listening to \"Hard Fork.\" This week, we hit the road and take a trip to the Googleplex to talk to Google's CEO, Sundar Pichai. [MUSIC PLAYING] So last week, we talked about Google's new chat bot called Bard, which is supposed to be their answer to ChatGPT and some of these other generative AI chat bots. And I think it's safe to say that the reaction among the public to Bard so far has been pretty lukewarm. My Twitter timeline is not full of screenshots of Bard conversations like it was of ChatGPT conversations late last year when that came out. It doesn't seem to have landed with nearly as big a splash. It was a little muted. You know, I think by this point, a lot of people have tried chat bots. And they feel like ChatGPT in particular gives really good results. And I think when people put these things through their paces, a lot of people felt like, I'm not sure if Bard is as good. Right. And that kind of fits with this narrative that has been developing in the AI community over the past year or two, which is that Google is somehow behind in this race for generative AI. They've been working on this stuff for a long time. Google certainly had a dominant position in AI research for many years. They came out with this thing, the Transformer, that revolutionized the field of AI and created the foundations for ChatGPT and all these other programs. But then the perception, at least, is that they kind of fell behind. A lot of their researchers left and did their own startups or went to competitors. They didn't really turn their research into products at a pace that people could actually use and appreciate. And they got sort of hamstrung by a lot of -- to hear people inside Google tell it -- big company politics and bureaucracy. And I think it's safe to say that they got sort of upstaged by OpenAI. With the release of ChatGPT last year, it seemed to catch Google off guard. And so in December, just a month after ChatGPT came out, my colleagues at \"The New York Times\" reported that Google's management had declared a code red. Yeah. And look, if you're a business and you're developing a lot of amazing technology, and no one else out there has released similar technology, that gives you a good reason to stay quiet and to not release it, right? We know that there are real safety concerns. There's responsibility issues, ethics issues, regulatory issues. Google actually did have a lot of good reasons to kind of sit on its hands. But then OpenAI forced its hand, and in a way that makes me wish I had used hands in a different way in the previous sentence because now I've just said hands too many times. Anyways, I love how dramatic a code red sounds. Makes you think like, what, are employees chained to their desks 24/7? My understanding is that what it meant for a lot of people there was all of a sudden, the goals that you had to get your next promotion, get your bonus, they were tied to whether you hit some goal related to AI. And the question is, is that going to get them where they want to go, or is it going to be a moment where they act a little panicked and they make a lot of mistakes? Yeah. And I think that Sundar Pichai is in a really fascinating and tough position here as the CEO of Google. And I think it's fair to say that they are more threatened than they have been in a very long time. That's right. And Google has been a relatively conflict-averse company for the past half decade-plus. They don't like picking fights. If they can just keep their heads down, quietly do their work, and print money with a monopolistic search advertising business, they're happy to do it. Totally. So we should continue to write columns where we're very nervous about where all this is going? As well as columnns where you're excited about the possible benefits of all of this. Yeah, I hear you on the whiplash. I feel whiplash every day just reading the news about AI. I can only imagine what you're feeling. I do too. Another question that people have about AI in the sort of medium and long term is about its effects on jobs. And there have been all these predictions about LLMs and what kinds of work they could replace or will replace. I actually -- I got a text from a software engineer a friend of mine the other day who was asking me if he should go into construction or welding because all of the software jobs are going to be taken by these large language models. And he was sort of joking, but sort of not. You have a lot of software engineers here at Google that work for you. How should they feel about that question? With any technology, you have adaptation. I think this one, there'll be a lot of societal adaptation. And as part of that, we all may need to course-correct in certain areas. To your specific question, I think for software engineers, there are two things that will also be true. One is some of the grunt work you're doing as part of programming is going to get better. So maybe it'll be more fun to program over time -- no different from the Google Docs make it easier to write. And so if you're a programmer, over time, having this collaborative IDs with the assistance built in, I think, is going to make it easier. The other thing that excites me is programming is going to become more accessible to more people. And so it's such an important role in the world. You're creating things. And today, the bar is very high. So we are going to evolve to a more natural language way of programming over time. So to me, that means things no different from to do a podcast -- to do something like this 40 years ago, just imagine what access you would need to have to be able to do an interview like this. We need a radio tower -- [LAUGHS] Yeah. [LAUGHS]: But you know, but we will think, this has enabled more people. Yeah. I think the same thing will be true for software engineering as well. So I think those are all important, exciting use cases to think about. Well I want to ask a more near-term question, near and dear to my heart -- kind of about media and publishing, but also search on the web. Today, lots of digital publishers rely on the traffic they get from Google. They get ad impressions. That pays their bills. When Bard is at its best, it answers my questions without me having to visit another website. I know you're cognizant of this. But man, if Bard gets as good as you want it to be, how does the web survive? I think through our work across, I think we'll be committed to getting it right with the publisher ecosystem. In search today, while these things are contentious, in search, we take pride, it's one of the largest sources of traffic. If I look at it year-on-year, the traffic we send outside has only grown. That's what we've accomplished as a company. Part of the reason we are also being careful with things like Bard, amongst many reasons, we do want to engage with the publisher ecosystem, not presume how things should be done. And so you will see us thoughtfully evolve there as well. Yeah, I mean, I know we can't really predict what the final form of all of this stuff will be, but I have to believe that, I don't know, in five years, what used to be the Google Search Bar is just essentially a command line that I can write in to get anything I want -- whether I want to change something on my phone, write myself a little app, access the subtotal of human knowledge, have it draft my emails. Does that feel like a potential final destination to you, or do I have it all wrong? You know, I mean, there's a part which is consistent with our mission to do that. But I think I want to be careful where Google has always been about helping you the way that makes sense to you. We have never thought of ourselves as the be-all and end-all of how we want people to interact. So while I think the possibility space is large, for me, it's important to do it in a way in which users use a lot of things, and we want to help them do things in a way that makes sense to them. And out of that North Star is whatever the answer it leads us to. But I don't want to get it -- so that's the way I think about it, at least in my head. Sundar, thank you for joining us. Thank you, Sundar. Thanks, Kevin, Casey. Pleasure, yeah. [FUNKY MUSIC PLAYING] Casey, we are back from the Googleplex. I really enjoyed our little field trip today. Thank you for that enlightening and enriching road trip, and also for allowing us to stop at In and Out for lunch on the way back. Yeah, it turns out if you order your fries well done, which is not on the menu, they arrive much crispier and more delicious. Yeah, that's a pro tip for you. You know, that wasn't my only takeaway from today, Kevin. Yeah, what'd you think? Well, you know, a lot of times when companies tell us about the new technologies they're introducing, they do so in a really grandiose way. And I was struck today by the humility that Sundar uses when he talks about where the company is now. He is not here to tell you that Bard is the best language model out there. He said that, in fact, it is quite limited. Yeah, he said -- he compared it to a souped-up Civic. [LAUGHS]: Yeah, which I wasn't expecting. But he broke a little news with us. He told us that Bard is going to be upgraded. And man, I'm really curious to see if Bard feels any different in a few days. Yeah, and I really was struck by what he called \"whiplash,\" where he's got people telling him, you know, you've got to move faster, and compete with GPT, and release everything you've got -- and then, also, this very real sense of like, didn't we get in trouble for doing this the last time with, you know, all the products that we released in the last decade? Shouldn't we be slow and deliberate? So I would want to switch jobs with them. Yeah. It sounds very hard. Also, I thought we would mostly be solving mysteries this week, but I feel like we are leaving with one, which is, who did order the Code Red at that company? Yeah, if you ordered the Code Red at Google, please write to us at hardfork@nytimes.com. We would love to hear from you. Also, before we go this week, a special thanks to the listener who wrote in to tell us that Spotify has a feature that allows you to exclude certain playlists, like my Sleep playlist, from your taste profile, which informs your recommendations and possibly what the AI DJ tells you to listen to. Yeah, I did that this week. So chill tracks will no longer be showing up in my Discover Weekly. That was a genius suggestion. Thank you to that listener -- and to all of our listeners. [RHYTHMIC MUSIC] \"Hard Fork\" is produced by Davis Land and Rachel Cohn. We're edited by Jen Poyant. This episode was fact-checked by Caitlin Love. Today's show was engineered by Alyssa Moxley. Original music by Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, and Rowan Niemisto. Special thanks to Paula Szuchman, Pui-Wing Tam, Nell Gallogly, Kate Lopresti, and Jeffrey Miranda. was seen as one of the most cutting-edge developers of A.I. But, with OpenAI’s release of ChatGPT, and other chatbots beating Google to market, is that distinction still the case? Google’s chief executive is in an unenviable position: Scramble to catch up or, in the face of potentially harmful technology, move slowly.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Today, Sundar Pichai on Google’s delicate balance between A.I. innovation and safety.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" And I think it's fair to say the early reviews were not amazing.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":7.99,"end":11.07,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I sort of imagined that we would discuss that at a really high level this week.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":11.07,"end":16.02,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"But then last week, I got a phone call.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":16.02,"end":17.97,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And someone I know at Google said, would you maybe want to talk this week to Sundar Pichai?","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":17.98,"end":24.72,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I said yes.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":24.72,"end":26.52,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"That didn't take you a lot of deliberation on that NEWTON","timecode":{"start":36.91,"end":38.64,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And you're listening to \"Hard Fork.\"","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":38.65,"end":40.682,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"This week, we hit the road and take a trip to the Googleplex to talk to Google's CEO, Sundar Pichai.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":40.682,"end":47.43,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"[MUSIC PLAYING]","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":47.44,"end":50.382,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"So last week, we talked about Google's new chat bot called Bard, which is supposed to be their answer to ChatGPT and some of these other generative AI chat bots.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":71.1,"end":80.72,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I think it's safe to say that the reaction among the public to Bard so far has been pretty lukewarm.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":80.72,"end":87.53,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"My Twitter timeline is not full of screenshots of Bard conversations like it was of ChatGPT conversations late last year when that came out.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":87.53,"end":96.08,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"It doesn't seem to have landed with nearly as big a splash.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":96.08,"end":98.538,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"It was a little muted.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":98.538,"end":100.038,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"You know, I think by this point, a lot of people have tried chat bots.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":100.038,"end":103.02,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And they feel like ChatGPT in particular gives really good results.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":103.02,"end":106.32,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I think when people put these things through their paces, a lot of people felt like, I'm not sure if Bard is as good.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":106.32,"end":111.68,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Right.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":111.69,"end":112.472,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And that kind of fits with this narrative that has been developing in the AI community over the past year or two, which is that Google is somehow behind in this race for generative AI.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":112.472,"end":124.52,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"They've been working on this stuff for a long time.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":124.52,"end":126.68,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Google certainly had a dominant position in AI research for many years.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":126.68,"end":131.24,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"They came out with this thing, the Transformer, that revolutionized the field of AI and created the foundations for ChatGPT and all these other programs.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":131.24,"end":142.31,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"But then the perception, at least, is that they kind of fell behind.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":142.32,"end":146.9,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"A lot of their researchers left and did their own startups or went to competitors.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":146.9,"end":151.34,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"They didn't really turn their research into products at a pace that people could actually use and appreciate.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":151.34,"end":158.42,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And they got sort of hamstrung by a lot of --","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":158.42,"end":162.65,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"to hear people inside Google tell it --","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":162.65,"end":164.48,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"big company politics and bureaucracy.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":164.48,"end":166.97,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I think it's safe to say that they got sort of upstaged by OpenAI.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":166.97,"end":172.13,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"With the release of ChatGPT last year, it seemed to catch Google off guard.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":172.14,"end":176.66,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And so in December, just a month after ChatGPT came out, my colleagues at \"The New York Times\" reported that Google's management had declared a code red.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":176.66,"end":184.718,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":184.718,"end":185.51,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And look, if you're a business and you're developing a lot of amazing technology, and no one else out there has released similar technology, that gives you a good reason to stay quiet and to not release it, right?","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":185.51,"end":196.37,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"We know that there are real safety concerns.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":196.37,"end":198.41,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"There's responsibility issues, ethics issues, regulatory issues.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":198.41,"end":202.79,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Google actually did have a lot of good reasons to kind of sit on its hands.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":202.8,"end":206.39,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"But then OpenAI forced its hand, and in a way that makes me wish I had used hands in a different way in the previous sentence because now I've just said hands too many times.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":206.39,"end":216.23,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Anyways, I love how dramatic a code red sounds.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":216.23,"end":220.25,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Makes you think like, what, are employees chained to their desks 24\u002F7?","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":220.25,"end":224.06,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"My understanding is that what it meant for a lot of people there was all of a sudden, the goals that you had to get your next promotion, get your bonus, they were tied to whether you hit some goal related to AI.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":224.07,"end":235.46,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And the question is, is that going to get them where they want to go, or is it going to be a moment where they act a little panicked and they make a lot of mistakes?","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":235.46,"end":243.41,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":243.41,"end":244.16,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I think that Sundar Pichai is in a really fascinating and tough position here as the CEO of Google.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":244.16,"end":250.16,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I think it's fair to say that they are more threatened than they have been in a very long time.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":250.16,"end":254.96,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"That's right.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":254.97,"end":256.085,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And Google has been a relatively conflict-averse company for the past half decade-plus.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":256.085,"end":261.17,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"They don't like picking fights.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":261.17,"end":262.52,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"If they can just keep their heads down, quietly do their work, and print money with a monopolistic search advertising business, they're happy to do it.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":262.52,"end":269.745,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Totally.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":269.745,"end":270.62,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And they also have this other problem, which is kind of a classic problem in business, which is the innovator's dilemma problem.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":270.62,"end":277.23,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"This is a term that was coined by Clayton Christensen a long time ago.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":277.23,"end":280.4,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"It's used to talk about the dynamics between new startups that enter a market and the incumbents in that market.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":280.4,"end":287.87,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And basically, Google is in the position of an incumbent.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":287.88,"end":291.56,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"It has this huge, profitable search business that it doesn't want to sort of diminish or leave behind in any way.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":291.56,"end":300.41,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"At the same time, it's got OpenAI and now Microsoft, which is partnering with OpenAI, who are potentially eating into their search business using these generative AI tools.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":300.41,"end":310.79,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And so they have to somehow figure out, how do we capitalize on generative AI without destroying our own search business?","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":310.79,"end":316.802,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Sometimes as a business journalist, you look at a situation, and you say, well, I know exactly what I would do there.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":316.802,"end":322.26,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"But when you present me with the problem that Google has right now, which is, how do you introduce generative AI and not blow up our whole search advertising business, that seems like a very tricky problem to me.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":322.26,"end":332.39,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"But I am not as certain as you are that there is a real existential risk here, although there might be.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":332.4,"end":339.02,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"I do think that there is a real generational opportunity, though -- that if they figure this out, there is a chance that they become an even more enormous company than they are today.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":339.02,"end":348.47,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Google plays a huge role in my life.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":348.47,"end":351.45,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"That's where my email is.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":351.45,"end":352.88,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"That's how I get around town.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":352.88,"end":354.78,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"It's how I waste hours of my life on YouTube.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":354.78,"end":357.87,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And when they introduce these generative tools across their entire suite of products in ways that we haven't even imagined yet, there's going to be enormous opportunity for them both financially, but also to kind of set the pace again.","speaker":"CASEY and saying, this stuff is moving awfully fast, and we're not sure that you've done all the safety work that you need to?","speaker":"CASEY PICHAI","timecode":{"start":2527.22,"end":2535.25,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"We have never thought of ourselves as the be-all and end-all of how we want people to interact.","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAI","timecode":{"start":2535.25,"end":2540.02,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"So while I think the possibility space is large, for me, it's important to do it in a way in which users use a lot of things, and we want to help them do things in a way that makes sense to them.","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAI","timecode":{"start":2540.03,"end":2554.76,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And out of that North Star is whatever the answer it leads us to.","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAI","timecode":{"start":2554.76,"end":2558.23,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"But I don't want to get it --","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAI","timecode":{"start":2558.23,"end":2559.95,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"so that's the way I think about it, at least in my head.","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAI","timecode":{"start":2559.95,"end":2562.773,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Sundar, thank you for joining us.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2562.773,"end":2564.69,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Thank you, Sundar.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2564.7,"end":2565.37,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Thanks, Kevin, Casey.","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAL","timecode":{"start":2565.38,"end":2566.27,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Pleasure, yeah.","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAL","timecode":{"start":2566.27,"end":2567.11,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"[FUNKY MUSIC PLAYING]","speaker":"SUNDAR PICHAL","timecode":{"start":2567.12,"end":2570.603,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Casey, we are back from the Googleplex.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2592.569,"end":2595.7,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"I really enjoyed our little field trip today.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2595.7,"end":2599,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Thank you for that enlightening and enriching road trip, and also for allowing us to stop at In and Out for lunch on the way back.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2599,"end":2605.28,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah, it turns out if you order your fries well done, which is not on the menu, they arrive much crispier and more delicious.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2605.79,"end":2610.76,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah, that's a pro tip for you.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2610.77,"end":2611.93,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"You know, that wasn't my only takeaway from today, Kevin.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2611.94,"end":2613.91,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah, what'd you think?","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2613.92,"end":2615.41,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Well, you know, a lot of times when companies tell us about the new technologies they're introducing, they do so in a really grandiose way.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2615.41,"end":2622.17,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And I was struck today by the humility that Sundar uses when he talks about where the company is now.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2622.17,"end":2628.34,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"He is not here to tell you that Bard is the best language model out there.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2628.34,"end":2632.21,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"He said that, in fact, it is quite limited.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2632.21,"end":2634.002,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah, he said -- he compared it to a souped-up Civic.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2634.002,"end":2636.752,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"[LAUGHS]: Yeah, which I wasn't expecting.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2636.752,"end":2639.512,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"But he broke a little news with us.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2639.512,"end":2640.97,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"He told us that Bard is going to be upgraded.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2640.97,"end":2643.55,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"And man, I'm really curious to see if Bard feels any different in a few days.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2643.55,"end":2648.14,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah, and I really was struck by what he called \"whiplash,\" where he's got people telling him, you know, you've got to move faster, and compete with GPT, and release everything you've got -- and then, also, this very real sense of like,","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2648.15,"end":2660.83,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"didn't we get in trouble for doing this the last time with, you know, all the products that we released in the last decade?","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2660.83,"end":2666.8,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Shouldn't we be slow and deliberate?","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2666.8,"end":2668.39,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"So I would want to switch jobs with them.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2668.39,"end":2670.52,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2670.53,"end":2670.64,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"It sounds very hard.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2670.65,"end":2672.015,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Also, I thought we would mostly be solving mysteries this week, but I feel like we are leaving with one, which is, who did order the Code Red at that company?","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2672.015,"end":2680.735,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah, if you ordered the Code Red at Google, please write to us at hardfork@nytimes.com.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2683.217,"end":2687.425,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"We would love to hear from you.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2687.435,"end":2689.3,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Also, before we go this week, a special thanks to the listener who wrote in to tell us that Spotify has a feature that allows you to exclude certain playlists, like my Sleep playlist, from your taste profile, which informs your recommendations","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2689.3,"end":2704.21,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"and possibly what the AI DJ tells you to listen to.","speaker":"KEVIN ROOSE","timecode":{"start":2704.21,"end":2706.642,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Yeah, I did that this week.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2706.642,"end":2708.35,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"So chill tracks will no longer be showing up in my Discover Weekly.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2708.35,"end":2712.82,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"That was a genius suggestion.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2712.82,"end":2714.42,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"Thank you to that listener -- and to all of our listeners.","speaker":"CASEY NEWTON","timecode":{"start":2714.42,"end":2716.837,"__typename":"AudioTimecode"},"__typename":"AudioTranscriptFragment"},{"text":"[RHYTHMIC MUSIC]","speaker":"CASEY
